image.name: P000020_001

profileText: a Delegate from Virginia; born at ``Rosewell,'' Gloucester County, Va., in 1749; studied under a private teacher and was graduated from the College of William and Mary, Williamsburg, Va.; studied law; was admitted to the bar and practiced; member of the State house of burgesses; moved to Spotsylvania County; Member of the Continental Congress in 1777; died on his estate, ``Mansfield,'' near Fredericksburg, Spotsylvania County, Va., in 1781; interment near Fredericksburg.

asset.name: P000020_001
asset.creditLine: Image courtesy of the New York Public Library

researchRecord.name: 1779, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Mann Page to Francis Lightfoot Lee written on February 8, 1779. In the letter, Mann Page writes regarding Silas Deane's defense of his conduct in France, published in the Pennsylvania Packet, December 5, 1778.

recordLocation.name: The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library

researchRecord.name: In the George Green Shackelford Collection, 1714-1835, 6 items.

recordLocation.name: The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library

researchRecord.name: In the Ralph Wormeley Papers, 1773-1802, 29 items and 1 volume.

recordLocation.name: The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library

researchRecord.name: In the Miscellaneous Manuscripts Collection, 1775, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Alexander Spotswood to Dudley Digges, William Fitzhugh, Joseph Jones, Mann Page, and other members of the Virginia Convention in which he volunteers to raise a Virginia regiment for service in the Revolutionary War. The letter was written on December 19, 1775.

researchRecord.name: In the Miscellaneous Manuscripts Collection, 1777, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Mann Page to an unidentified recipient written in 1777.

researchRecord.name: 1894, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John T. Parham to Mann Page written on November 24, 1895. In the letter, John Parham writes to give his recommendations to Mann Page for members to serve on a committee of a Masonic organization. John Parham also expresses the wish that Mann Page remain as Grand Master of Masons of Virginia for another year.
